repnme.cdata!:
Egypt - Higher Education Enhancement
            Project; Yemen - Higher Education Learning and Innovation
            Project; Jordan - Higher Education Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Higher Education
            Enhancement Project for Egypt were as follows: outcomes were
            moderately satisfactory, risk to development outcome was low
            to negligible, Bank performance was moderately
            unsatisfactory, and borrower performance was moderately
            satisfactory. Ratings for the Higher Education Learning and
            Innovation Project for Yemen were as follows: outcomes were
            unsatisfactory, risk to development outcome was significant,
            Bank performance was highly unsatisfactory, and borrower
            performance was unsatisfactory. Ratings for the Higher
            Education Project for Jordan were as follows: outcomes were
            unsatisfactory, risk to development outcome was significant,
            Bank performance was unsatisfactory, and borrower
            performance was unsatisfactory. Some lessons learned
            included: the introduction of a widely adopted change model
            needs to be preceded by sufficient sector analytic work to
            create an appreciation of the complexities (implications) of
            the changes and of the likely sources of resistance. Such
            analysis could help determine the parts of the model that
            are appropriate to the context, and the pace of adoption.
            Efforts to improve the quality of higher education need to
            improve student learning outcomes. Standard assessment of
            student achievement in higher education is challenging, both
            in a technical and a political sense. Moves in that
            direction have already begun in Egypt and Jordan.
            Restructuring higher education courses and programs and
            ensuring appropriate private sector participation in
            decision-making are not in themselves sufficient to ensure
            that reforms will result in more employable graduates.
            Higher education systems need to systematically monitor the
            labor market relevance of their offerings and the success of
            their graduates.

14494311.trustfund:
TF025659-PHRD: HIGHER EDUC. &
            SCIENTIFIC RESEARCH PROJ.,TF039610-EGYPT:  HIGHER EDUCATION PROJECT

repnme.cdata!:
Yemen - Higher Education Learning and
            Innovation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Higher Education
            Learning and Innovation Project for Yemen were as follows:
            outcomes were moderately unsatisfactory, the risk to
            development outcome was substantial, the Bank performance
            was unsatisfactory, and the Borrower performance was also
            unsatisfactory. Some lessons learned included: it is crucial
            to have a rigorous monitoring and evaluation plan for all
            project activities to detect obstacles at early stages and
            act quickly to prevent worsening of the problem and delay in
            implementation. Furthermore, it is important to regularly
            evaluate the quality of Technical Assistance (TA)
            activities. Throughout the implementation of this project,
            there was no solid and systematic evaluation of the
            effectiveness and relevance of TA activities except for
            contractors' final reports which contained general
            self-assessment on their TA activities. Keeping decision
            makers informed of project progress is critical for
            appropriate readjustment of project scope and activities.
            Monitoring and Evaluation (M&E) plays a key role in this
            as it enables the effective collection and dissemination of
            data and information to a wider group, including
            beneficiaries. As seen with the diminished role of the
            steering committee, the absence of M&E resulted in
            missed opportunities to effectively guide the project as the
            implementation environment evolved. Project re-structuring
            should be considered at any time during project
            implementation if substantial changes are being proposed by
            the Borrower or additional donor resources become available
            in an evolving environment. This project should have been
            considered for restructuring to reflect a changing
            government approach to reform and to re-align new objectives
            with revised outcome indicators.

5085552.trustfund:
TF090739-JAPAN CTF - FY08: GENERAL BBMC
            (ALL BANK BORROWING MEMBER COUNTRIES/ALL

repnme.cdata!:
Yemen - Higher Education Learning and
            Innovation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objective of the Higher
            Education Learning and Innovation Project, is to assist in
            the preparation of a higher education reform strategy, and
            to pilot initial phases of its implementation, which, if
            successful, would prod the development of a second,
            medium-term phase of the reform, likely to require donor
            support, and further Bank lending. Three main components
            will support: 1) governance, by developing a strategy and
            medium-term development plan for the education sector, and a
            legislative and institutional framework, promoting improved
            management. Activities include a participatory higher
            education reform development, and the preparation of
            medium-term investment program, comprising as well capacity
            building to the Ministry of Higher Education staff, and,
            technical training to the two universities involved, for
            their management, and accountability assumption; 2)
            financing of the redesign process of the universities'
            budget structures, and procedures, to facilitate flexible
            allocation of resources, and efficient expenditures.
            Moreover, assistance for the development of equitable
            funding mechanisms for universities will be provided, to
            increase girls' education, and attendance by diverse
            income-level groups. Information management systems, and
            related training will be adapted to provide institutional
            management services; and, 3) quality of education, by
            upgrading the faculty in selected disciplines (medicine,
            education, and commerce), and piloting strategic
            initiatives, such as evaluation methods, and teaching
            skills, educational programs redesign, and an information
            communications technology network linking central, and
            faculty libraries via intranet access to Internet resources.
